gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19115-2 Geographic Information - Metadata - Part 2: Extensions for Imagery and Gridded Data

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: Raw files from DSG hydrophone from Middle Marsh, Rachel Carson Estuarine Research Reserve from 2014 (Larval settlement soundscapes project)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Raw files from low-power SoundTrap recorders and hydrophones Dataset Description: <p>This dataset contains passive acoustic recordings within the Middle Marsh portion of the Rachel Carson Estuarine Research Reserve, NC. Each file contains raw acoustic records collected using a low-power SoundTrap recorder and hydrophone (Ocean Instruments New Zealand). The hydrophone was configured to record for 130 seconds every 20 minutes at a 96 kHz sample rate.</p><p><strong>Related References:</strong></p><p>Additional information about this dataset can be found in:</p><p>Ricci SW, Eggleston DB, Bohnenstiehl DR, Lillis A. Temporal Soundscape Patterns and Processes in an Estuarine Reserve. Marine Ecology Progress Series (in review).</p><p>Ricci SW, Eggleston DB, Bohnenstiehl DR. Use of underwater soundscapes to characterize nocturnal fish behavior and habitat use within a complex mosaic of estuarine habitats. Bulletin of Marine Science (in review).</p> Acquisition Description: <p>Beginning in June of 2014, a short-term effort was initiated to record ambient underwater sound at high temporal resolution, within the Middle Marsh portion of the Rachel Carson Estuarine Research Reserve. This was accomplished using a low-power SoundTrap recorder and hydrophone (Ocean Instruments New Zealand).</p><p>The instrument was strapped vertically to a metal post and positioned ~0.15m above the seafloor, and in water of sufficient depth so that it remained submerged during spring low tides. At low tide, the SoundTraps were submerged at least 0.15 m, and at high tide, the SoundTraps were submerged in approximately 1 m of water, depending on the magnitude of the tide.</p><p>Three individual deployments were carried out using eight SoundTraps between 12 June 2014 and 31 August 2014. Deployment start and end dates for each site are listed in Table 1. The instrument was programmed to record for 130 seconds every 20 minutes at a 96 kHz sample rate. The SoundTrap analog signal is digitized at a fixed rate of 288 kHz. A digital anti-alias filter, with a cutoff frequency of 0.45 times the desired sample rate, is then applied before decimation. Consequently, at our sample rate of 96 kHz, the useable (-3 dB) bandwidth of these recordings is 0.020-43.0 kHz. In total, 36,870 separate 2-minute recordings were made as part of this monitoring initiative.</p><p>The data may be read into MATLAB using functions included in MATLAB.</p><p>Example:<br />% Set calibration<br />cal=10^(STcalibration/20);</p><p>[y,fs]=audioread(‘filename.wav’); %read in audiofile<br />y=y(fs*5:end) %remove first 5 seconds that have calibration sound<br />y=(y-mean(y))*cal; %demeaned and response correct to uPa</p>

gmd:credit.gmx:Anchor: Funding provided by NSF Division of Ocean Sciences (NSF OCE) Award Number: OCE-1234688 Award URL: http://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward.do?AwardNumber=1234688

If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: Can you hear me now? Estuarine soundscapes and their role in larval settlement

gmd:name.gmx:Anchor: Can you hear me now? Estuarine soundscapes and their role in larval settlement

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The overall goal of this study is to advance our general understanding of the role of underwater sound in biological oceanography by characterizing spatiotemporal variation in an estuarine soundscape, and determine if this variation affects the settlement of larval invertebrates. The investigators will use larval bivalves and subtidal oyster reefs in Pamlico Sound, North Carolina as a study system. A combination of field and laboratory experiments will be used to test the effects of sound on larval behaviors and settlement. The underwater sonic environment has the potential to provide meaningful sensory information to all aquatic animals. Acoustic signals are transmitted relatively large distances, are present at all depths, and reflect biological and physical characteristics of the environment, while other cues (e.g. light, chemicals) are rapidly attenuated from the source. Sound is well established as an orientation and habitat selection cue for marine mammals and fishes, and has recently emerged as a potentially important contributor to larval settlement. Building capacity (knowledge, expertise, equipment) for integrating geophysical aspects of underwater sound propagation with ecological and oceanographic processes is central to bio-physical studies of larval connectivity and recruitment in marine systems. It also informs our understanding of the potential adverse effects of noise pollution in the ocean and may elucidate untested benefits of marine reserves - ultimately leading to healthier and better managed oceans and estuaries. The project supports graduate, postdoctoral and undergraduate student training, as well as educational outreach programs that span local, regional and national levels
Middle Marsh portion of the Rachel Carson Estuarine Research Reserve

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659545.rdf Name: site Units: unitless Description: recording site http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659546.rdf Name: lat Units: decimal degrees Description: latitude; north is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659547.rdf Name: lon Units: decimal degrees Description: longitude; east is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659548.rdf Name: deployment Units: unitless Description: deployment identification http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659549.rdf Name: ISO_DateTime_Local_start Units: year-month-day-hour-minute-second Description: start date and time; ISO 8601:2004(E) format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659550.rdf Name: ISO_DateTime_Local_end Units: year-month-day-hour-minute-second Description: end date and time; ISO 8601:2004(E) format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659551.rdf Name: SoundTrap_num Units: unitless Description: identification number of recorder http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659552.rdf Name: calibration Units: decibel microPascals per count (dB uPa/count) Description: hydrophone calibration: sound pressure level in water http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659553.rdf Name: first_file Units: unitless Description: first sound file in series at a particular site and deployment http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659554.rdf Name: last_file Units: unitless Description: last sound file in series at a particular site and deployment http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659555.rdf Name: file_size_GB Units: Gigabytes Description: size of zipped sound file http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/659556.rdf Name: file_link Units: unitless Description: link to download .zip sound file

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: recording site; General Description: Sampling site identification.

PI-supplied Description: latitude; north is positive; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: longitude; east is positive; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.
PI-supplied Description: deployment identification; General Description: deployment number, equivalent to station or cast

PI-supplied Description: start date and time; ISO 8601:2004(E) format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS; General Description: Date/Time (Local) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS[.xx]2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Note the Time Zone (TZ) as +/-HH:MMTime Zone signage is for conversion from local to UTCWest Coast USA in summer is +7 (add 7 hrs to local time for UTC)

PI-supplied Description: end date and time; ISO 8601:2004(E) format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS; General Description: Date/Time (Local) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS[.xx]2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Note the Time Zone (TZ) as +/-HH:MMTime Zone signage is for conversion from local to UTCWest Coast USA in summer is +7 (add 7 hrs to local time for UTC)
PI-supplied Description: identification number of recorder; General Description: instrument serial number, definition specific to the data set in which it appears.
PI-supplied Description: hydrophone calibration: sound pressure level in water; General Description: association with a community-wide standard parameter is not yet defined
PI-supplied Description: first sound file in series at a particular site and deployment; General Description: File name
PI-supplied Description: last sound file in series at a particular site and deployment; General Description: File name
PI-supplied Description: size of zipped sound file; General Description: Size of file. Maybe in MB, GB, TB, etc.
PI-supplied Description: link to download .zip sound file; General Description: Link to file (such as a data file or document).

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p>Beginning in June of 2014, a short-term effort was initiated to record ambient underwater sound at high temporal resolution, within the Middle Marsh portion of the Rachel Carson Estuarine Research Reserve. This was accomplished using a low-power SoundTrap recorder and hydrophone (Ocean Instruments New Zealand).</p><p>The instrument was strapped vertically to a metal post and positioned ~0.15m above the seafloor, and in water of sufficient depth so that it remained submerged during spring low tides. At low tide, the SoundTraps were submerged at least 0.15 m, and at high tide, the SoundTraps were submerged in approximately 1 m of water, depending on the magnitude of the tide.</p><p>Three individual deployments were carried out using eight SoundTraps between 12 June 2014 and 31 August 2014. Deployment start and end dates for each site are listed in Table 1. The instrument was programmed to record for 130 seconds every 20 minutes at a 96 kHz sample rate. The SoundTrap analog signal is digitized at a fixed rate of 288 kHz. A digital anti-alias filter, with a cutoff frequency of 0.45 times the desired sample rate, is then applied before decimation. Consequently, at our sample rate of 96 kHz, the useable (-3 dB) bandwidth of these recordings is 0.020-43.0 kHz. In total, 36,870 separate 2-minute recordings were made as part of this monitoring initiative.</p><p>The data may be read into MATLAB using functions included in MATLAB.</p><p>Example:<br />% Set calibration<br />cal=10^(STcalibration/20);</p><p>[y,fs]=audioread(‘filename.wav’); %read in audiofile<br />y=y(fs*5:end) %remove first 5 seconds that have calibration sound<br />y=(y-mean(y))*cal; %demeaned and response correct to uPa</p>

<p>No processing. These are the raw data files in .wav format.</p><p><strong>BCO-DMO Processing:</strong></p><p>- added conventional header with dataset name, PI name, version date<br />- renamed parameters to BCO-DMO standard<br />- created flat file with submitted metadata including lat and lon, date/time, recording parameters, and links to download the data files.<br />- calculated ISO_TimeDate_Local_start and _end</p>

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: PI Supplied Instrument Description:Ocean Instruments New Zealand Instrument Name: Hydrophone Instrument Short Name: Instrument Description: A hydrophone is a microphone designed to be used underwater for recording or listening to underwater sound. Most hydrophones are based on a piezoelectric transducer that generates electricity when subjected to a pressure change.

PI Supplied Instrument Name: PI Supplied Instrument Description:SoundTrap recorder and hydrophone (Ocean Instruments New Zealand). Instrument Name: Acoustic Recorder Instrument Short Name: Instrument Description: An acoustic recorder senses and records acoustic signals from the environment.
